citation.biblCit: Population Research Laboratory, 2015, "Alberta Survey, 2005", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10571, UAL Dataverse, V4

AuthEnty.affiliation: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

stdyInfo.abstract: The 2005 Alberta Survey (AS) was the 18th annual provincial survey administered by the Population Research Laboratory (PRL). This omnibus survey of households in the province of Alberta continues to enable academic researchers, government departments, and non-profit organizations to explore a wide range of research topics in a structured research framework and environment.

sumDscr.universe: The target participant population for telephone interviewing was all persons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, were living in a dwelling unit in Alberta that could be contacted by direct dialling. From this population, three samples were drawn to cover Alberta, including Edmonton metropolitan area, Calgary metropolitan area, and the rest of the province.

dataColl.sampProc: SAMPLING DESIGN Main Features of Design: a. The province of Alberta was delineated into three areas for telephone interviewing, as follows: (1) Edmonton Metropolitan Area (2) Calgary Metropolitan Area (3) Remainder of the Province (Other Alberta). b. Two-stage selection process (1) Selection of households (2) Selection of respondent within each household. To permit the analysis of each area as a separate entity, a minimum sample size of 400 or more for each area of the province was instituted. The target participant population for telephone interviewing was all persons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, were living in a dwelling unit in Alberta that could be contacted by direct dialling. From this population, three samples were drawn to cover Alberta, including Edmonton metropolitan area, Calgary metropolitan area, and the rest of the province. A Random-Digit Dialling approach was used to ensure that respondents had an equal chance to be contacted whether or not their household was listed in a telephone directory. The PRL has developed a database of five-digit telephone banks (e.g. 403/780-xxx-xx) covering all of Alberta. The 2005 Alberta Survey sample was drawn from this provincial database by using a computer program to select a simple random sample of number banks for each area, and appending a random number between 00 and 99 to each number selected. Duplicate telephone numbers were purged from the computer-generated list. Within the household, one eligible person was selected as the respondent. The mean length of the interview in the 2005 survey was 35.2 minutes. A respondent within each household was selected on the basis of gender using the following selection guidelines to ensure an equal selection of male and female participants. a. He/she must be 18 years of age or older. b. If an adult male answers the phone and is willing to be interviewed, he is the respondent. c. If an adult female answers the phone and there is an adult male present who is willing to be interviewed, interview the male. If the male is not willing to be interviewed, and the female is willing, interview the female. d. If an adult female answers the phone and there is no adult male present, choose her as the respondent.
dataColl.weight: The weighting factors used for the 2005 survey are as follows: Edmonton Metropolitan 0.949299, Calgary Metropolitan 0.991455, and Other Alberta 1.059497.

var.name: a20

var.name: a21

var.name: a22
var.labl: There is so much traffic on the streets that it makes it difficult or unpleasant to walk in my neighbourhood.

var.name: a23
var.labl: I see many people engaging in physical activity in my neighbourhood.

var.name: a24
var.labl: There are many interesting things to look at while walking in my neighborhood.

var.name: e3
var.labl: The government covers the costs of long-term care as part of our health care system.

var.name: e4

var.name: e5
var.labl: The government closely regulates the quality and services provided in long-term care facilities.

var.name: e6
var.labl: Provincial regulations should guarantee that long-term care facilities have registered nurses and other professionals on staff.

var.name: e7
var.labl: Residents or their families should be responsible for the full costs of long-term care services.

var.name: e8
var.labl: There is a growing problem in Alberta with residents or patients in long-term care not getting safe and adequate care.

var.name: e9
var.labl: It would be wrong to cut services and increase residents' charges by changing the name of long-term care and calling it assisted living instead.

var.name: e10

var.name: e11
var.labl: The provincial government should only be responsible for income subsidies that provide a minimum level of care for those people who cannot afford their own care.

var.name: e12
var.labl: When private investors are in the business of providing continuing or long-term care services, they have a real incentive to cut costs and quality.

var.name: h1
var.labl: I want to learn what science says about the dangers of mad cow disease.

var.name: h2
var.labl: I find television shows that try to teach science, like Nova and Daily Planet, to be interesting.

var.name: h3
var.labl: Reading a book about new scientific discoveries is an enjoyable way to spend my free time.

var.name: h4
var.labl: If I had a disease, I would learn as much as possible what medical science says about it.

var.name: h5
var.labl: Many times I wish I understood the scientific explanation for things more than I do.

var.name: h6
var.labl: I often read newspaper or magazine articles on new scientific discoveries.

var.name: h7
var.labl: I am interested in learning science only when it relates directly to my life.

var.name: h8
var.labl: I find science articles in newspapers and magazines too difficult to understand.

var.name: h9
var.labl: Even if I never use them, knowing the scientific explanations for things makes my life more interesting.

var.name: h10
var.labl: It is important to know some science even if your line of work does not require it.

var.name: h11
var.labl: Science (either general or specialized) should be a required subject for all students in all grades from kindergarten to grade 12.

var.name: h12
var.labl: School provided me all the scientific knowledge I need in my life.

var.name: h13
var.labl: The major aim of teaching science in school should be to encourage more young people into careers in science.

var.name: h14
var.labl: Schools should concentrate more on teaching students the facts of science than on teaching them to think like scientists.

var.name: h15
var.labl: The quality of science education in Alberta schools is adequate.

var.name: h16
var.labl: Students need a stronger science education today than in the past.

var.name: h17
var.labl: Improving science education in schools should be one of our most important educational priorities.

var.name: h18
var.labl: Kindergarten to grade six teachers need a good background in university science courses.

var.name: i1
var.labl: Reading to babies and children before they begin school gives them a good start in learning to read.

var.name: i2
var.labl: Parents should read to their children every day.

var.name: i3
var.labl: When it is appropriate, parents should talk about their own reading to their children.

var.name: i4
var.labl: Parents should encourage their children to read every day.

var.name: i5
var.labl: Parents should talk to their children about what their children are reading.

var.name: i6
var.labl: Being able to say the words on the page is the most important part of reading.

var.name: i7
var.labl: If children make mistakes when they are reading out loud, they should always be corrected.

var.name: i8
var.labl: Understanding what you read is more important than saying all the words correctly.

var.name: i9
var.labl: The number of books in the home is less important than reading to children.

var.name: i10
var.labl: Most parents know the best ways to read to children.

var.name: i11
var.labl: Most parents know the best books to read to children.

var.name: i12
var.labl: Most parents know the difference between a book that is to be read to a child, and a book that a child is to read.

var.name: i13
var.labl: Most parents understand how children are being taught to read in school.

var.name: i14
var.labl: Most teachers do not tell parents how to help their children with reading at home.

var.name: i15
var.labl: Teaching children to read well should be the main focus of schooling.

var.name: i16
var.labl: Most teachers know the best way to teach a child to read well.

var.name: i17
var.labl: Schools do not teach children to read well enough to be lifelong readers.

var.name: j1
var.labl: Do you currently have parenting responsibilities for any children aged 17 years or less?

var.name: j2
var.labl: Single mothers with a child aged less than 6 years who are receiving welfare should be required to undertake training or look for work.

var.name: j3
var.labl: In order to be happy in life, it is important to have a paying job.

var.name: j4
var.labl: Many working mothers seem to care more about being successful at work than meeting the needs of their children.

var.name: j5
var.labl: If both partners in a couple work, they should share equally in the housework and care of children.

var.name: j6
var.labl: Whatever career a woman may have, her most important role in life is still that of being a mother.

var.name: j7
var.labl: Mothers who don't really need the money should not work.

var.name: j8
var.labl: As long as the care is good, it is fine for children under 3 years of age to be placed in child care all day for 5 days a week.

var.name: j9
var.labl: As long as the care is good, it is fine for children of primary school age to be placed in child care all day for 5 days a week.

var.name: j10
var.labl: My work has a positive effect on my children.

var.name: j11
var.labl: The fact I am working makes me a better parent.

var.name: j12
var.labl: Working leaves me with too little time or energy to be the kind of parent I want to be.

var.name: l1
var.labl: Gays and lesbians should have the right to get married.

var.name: l2
var.labl: Marriage should be limited to one man and one woman.

var.name: l3
var.labl: Same-sex couples should be granted an alternative arrangement, not marriage.

var.name: l4
var.labl: There is nothing wrong about sexual relations between two adults of the same sex.

var.name: l5
var.labl: Women are more kindhearted than men.

var.name: l6
var.labl: Women are just as suitable as men for dangerous occupations such as fire-fighting.

var.name: l7
var.labl: Most women want to be protected by men.

var.name: l8
var.labl: Men are less likely to let emotions cloud their thinking than women.

var.name: l9
var.labl: Parents should emphasize appearance more for their daughters than for their sons.

var.name: l10
var.labl: Boys are naturally more aggressive than girls.

var.name: l11
var.labl: Boys should be encouraged to be daring more than girls.

var.name: l12
var.labl: Boys should be encouraged to be sensitive just as much as girls.
